maya.definition: Maya is the cosmic illusion that makes the one, indivisible reality (Brahman) appear as the diverse material world.
key_concepts: The world appears real but is ultimately transient and illusory.
Maya creates duality—subject and object, self and other.
It is not absolute; it depends on Brahman for existence.
examples_in_daily_life: Mistaking material wealth as the source of happiness.
Attachment to possessions and relationships as permanent.
Thinking success or failure is ultimate reality.
effects_on_perception: Creates false sense of individuality and separation.
Generates desires and attachments leading to suffering.
Veils the truth that all beings are one with Brahman.

avidya.definition: Avidya is ignorance—the fundamental misunderstanding of reality that causes attachment and suffering.

origin.meaning: Derived from Sanskrit 'a-vidya', meaning 'absence of knowledge'.

key_concepts: Ignorance of the true Self (Atman) as Brahman.
Mistaking the body and mind for the Self.
Root cause of desire, attachment, and karmic bondage.

role_in_philosophy.advaita: Avidya sustains Maya and prevents realization of non-duality.
role_in_philosophy.cause_of_suffering: Ignorance leads to ego and worldly entanglement.

maya_and_avidya.relationship_between_maya_and_avidya: Maya is the cosmic illusion, while Avidya is individual ignorance. Together, they create the perception of multiplicity and bondage to Samsara.
